Americans are increasingly fracturing as a people, and some are taking the extraordinary step of moving to escape a political or social climate they abhor. Democrats have left Iowa, Texas and other red states as Republicans have moved from California, Oregon and other blue ones, often over their views on issues like abortion, transgender rights, school curriculums, guns, race and a host of other matters.

While there is no precise count of how many Americans have relocated as a result of politics and social issues, interviews with demographers and people who have moved or are considering moving, as well as a review of social-media postings and polling, show that the phenomenon is real.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about two families ‚Äî the Nobles of Iowa, who moved to blue Minnesota, and the Huckinses of Oregon, who moved to red Missouri ‚Äî whose journeys illustrate the divide in America  Photos by @hlswift

Graphic imagery and footage has flooded social media since Hamas terrorists attacked Israel, killing more than 1,200 people. Bogus claims are also circulating, and risk obscuring real evidence of atrocities.

False claims around the Israel attacks include recycled videos and a game clip. They also include old and unrelated videos and photos with inaccurate claims, and fabricated assertions about the involvement of countries like the U.S. and Ukraine. This is adding confusion and deception to an already chaotic moment. And the false information circulating online risks clouding evidence that is emerging as Israeli soldiers retake control of places that were attacked.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about some of the inaccurate material circulating online.

Buses packed with Venezuelan migrants are now arriving in downtown Chicago day and night, as the number of arrivals has doubled in recent weeks. City officials are struggling to open more shelters, while more than 2,300 migrants are sleeping at police stations, in lobbies and outside in makeshift camps.

At the city‚Äôs airports, migrants who have just landed sleep on the floor, many with babies and toddlers, as local officials plead for more help from the federal government.

Like New York and some other U.S. cities, Chicago is straining to provide for the growing numbers of migrants who have arrived over the last year. But with the city‚Äôs infamously cold winter fast approaching, volunteers and leaders are worried that things will only get worse.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about Chicago‚Äôs escalating migrant crisis. Photos by @jaymiey

Steve Scalise, the representative from Louisiana, narrowly scraped together enough Republican support on Wednesday to become his party‚Äôs choice to lead the House following Representative Kevin McCarthy‚Äôs ouster last week. But deep divisions in the GOP ranks threatened to complicate Scalise‚Äôs election as speaker.

The choice is a vote of confidence for the party‚Äôs No. 2 House leader, but the rifts in his conference could still make for a chaotic election in the full chamber. Mere minutes after a slim majority of Republicans voted in a closed-door party meeting to select him as the party‚Äôs candidate, Scalise‚Äôs fate was thrown into doubt. Several GOP lawmakers announced they would not back him on the House floor without concessions, complaining of a rushed process to choose a new speaker. Republicans delayed a vote of the full House that had been planned for midafternoon so the party could regoup.

Tap the link in our bio for updates on the House vote for a new speaker. Photo by @haiyunjiang

Two 6.3-magnitude earthquakes hit Afghanistan on Saturday, the deadliest to strike the country in decades. Hundreds of Afghans in one of the worst-hit districts, Zinda Jan, have been struggling to come to terms with the almost unfathomable destruction.

In a matter of minutes, several entire villages were transformed into mounds of dust. Nearly everyone in the area lost at least one relative when their homes crumbled. Many have lost most, if not all, of their immediate family.

Early Wednesday, another 6.3-magnitude earthquake hit near Herat City, sending people running from their homes for the second time in five days. Tap the link in our bio to read the full story. Photos by @victorblue

Israeli airstrikes have flattened mosques in Gaza and killed people worshiping inside, witnesses and authorities in Gaza said. Israel says its strikes are targeting centers of operations of Hamas, the armed Palestinian group that controls Gaza. It confirmed hitting the mosques, saying it was targeting Hamas infrastructure or fighters inside those buildings.

The strikes are part of Israel‚Äôs response to the attack on Saturday, when hundreds of Palestinian gunmen swept across Israel‚Äôs border with Gaza, killing more than 1,000 people and taking around 150 hostages.

Israel‚Äôs fighter jets and artillery have struck targets in Gaza frequently over the years as part of the longstanding conflict between the Palestinians and Israel. But from the first day of this new war, residents of Gaza and health authorities have said that this time the strikes have been indiscriminately hitting structures that haven‚Äôt regularly been targeted, such as schools, hospitals and mosques.

As Israeli soldiers regain control of areas near Gaza that came under attack, they are finding evidence of the massacre of civilians by Hamas terrorists. The evidence includes security camera footage and cellphone videos, photographs from residents and professionals, and the accounts of witnesses who survived the initial attacks. The material shows that Palestinian gunmen attacked Israeli civilians in all the mundane places of a Saturday morning in southern Israel ‚Äî at an outdoor festival and in their homes, on familiar roads and in the middle of town ‚Äî places where soldiers and the police were as surprised by the violence as neighbors, families and friends.

Hamas gunmen, hitting more than 20 sites in southern Israel, killed more than 1,000 people, including women and children, and abducted an estimated 150 more people. Officials from Israel, the U.S., Europe and the UN have condemned the violence in the starkest terms.

Yonatan Ziegen said he last heard from his mother on Oct. 7 when they were texting during an assault on Be‚Äôeri, an Israeli kibbutz. She messaged him to say that assailants were in the house before going silent. 

Ziegen is still waiting to hear whether his mother has been found. More than 100 people were killed in the attack on Be‚Äôeri, according to the ZAKA relief organization. The Israeli government said at least 150 Israelis had been taken hostage by Hamas assailants since Oct. 7.

Community health workers globally put in long hours to protect people in developing countries from diseases such as malaria, Covid-19 and HIV. But most are compensated minimally, or not paid at all.

Now, spurred by frustrations that arose during the Covid pandemic and connected by digital technologies, like WhatsApp, that have reached even remote areas, community health workers are organizing to fight for fair compensation. For more than a billion people in low-income countries, community health workers deliver the main, and sometimes only, health care available.

The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria recently became the first major international health organization to require countries that receive its grants to budget what delivery would be done by community health workers and the funding gap for remunerating them. Still, only 34 of the 193 member states in the U.N. have formalized the role of community health workers with training, accreditation and minimum wages. And 86% of community health workers in Africa are completely unpaid.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how community health workers in Africa are changing their strategies to get fair pay. Photos by @tiksajaarraa

Eight-year-old A. Altannar is at the center of a struggle between the Dalai Lama and the Chinese Communist Party.

On a visit to a vast monastery in the capital city of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, A. Altannar‚Äôs father brought him and his toddler twin brother into a room where they and seven other boys were given a secret test. A. Altannar behaved differently from the other children. He picked out a set of prayer beads and put it around his neck. He rang a bell used for meditation. He walked over to a monk in the room and playfully climbed on his legs.

The monks had found the 10th reincarnation of the Bogd, and for the next seven years, they kept his identity a secret.

But who gets to be the Bogd is a sensitive question with implications for Mongolia, China and Tibet. So when the Dalai Lama appeared with A. Altannar in public this year at a ceremony in India, it was a defiant assertion of his influence over Tibetan Buddhism and a challenge to Beijing‚Äôs claims over succession. And it put Mongolia on the spot, straining its delicate relationship with China.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how this boy was selected in an ancient tradition and how he may put pressure on the Chinese Communist Party. Photos by @nytchangster and @inomad

During Paris Fashion Week, almost every color could be spotted on the streets and the runways.

On the streets, summery yellows mixed with autumnal oranges. Dries Van Noten and Valentino evoked springtime by filling their collections with vibrant greens. Aside from at the Nina Ricci show in Paris, where people of different sizes walked the runway, models were ‚Äúas skinny as I‚Äôve seen them in the more than 10 years I‚Äôve been documenting fashion weeks,‚Äù writes the photographer @simbarashecha. And as suggested by the spate of colorful collections this season, variety is never a bad thing.

Tap the link in our bio for @simbarashecha‚Äôs full rundown of style outside ‚Äî and inside ‚Äî Paris Fashion Week.

Three years after its marathon voyage across the Central Arctic Ocean, the German scientific research ship Polarstern ‚Äî a 400-foot double-hulled icebreaker, owned by the German government and operated by the Alfred Wegener Institute ‚Äî has once again reached the North Pole. This time the expedition is two months rather than a full year. The goal of the scientists on board is the same: to gain a better understanding of how the Central Arctic is changing as the planet warms.

Sea-ice coverage in the Arctic shrinks in spring and summer and reaches a minimum in mid-September. This year, it‚Äôs on track to be the sixth lowest on record. The current expedition, called ArcWatch ‚Äî which began in early August in northern Norway and ends Oct. 1 at the ship‚Äôs home port, Bremerhaven, Germany ‚Äî includes more than 50 biologists, chemists and other scientists using specialized instruments brought along for the voyage as well as two helicopters.

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel warned on Sunday of a ‚Äúlong and difficult war‚Äù ahead, a day after Palestinian militants launched one of the biggest attacks on the country in years from the Gaza Strip. New Zealand has long waged war against its invasive species. With no native land mammals, the island nation has tried to eliminate or sharply reduce ‚Äúpest‚Äù species introduced during colonization that harm indigenous birds, bats, frogs, fish, marine mammals and plant life.

‚ÄòWe Are at War,‚Äô Netanyahu Says After Hamas Attacks

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel ordered a call-up of reservists after Palestinian militants fired thousands of rockets, invaded several Israeli towns and took hostages. Nearly 300 people have been killed, according to Israeli and Palestinian officials.

The Israeli military said that the militants had entered at least 22 Israeli towns and abducted soldiers and civilians, including an older grandmother. Residents of Israeli border towns told broadcasters that gunmen were moving door to door, looking for civilians. Unverified footage appeared to show Palestinian fighters transporting captured Israeli civilians and bodies through the Gaza Strip.

The timing of the assault, at one of the most difficult moments in Israel‚Äôs history, was striking. It followed months of profound anxiety in Israel about the cohesion of its society and the readiness of its military, a crisis set off by the government‚Äôs efforts to reduce the power of the judiciary. And the violence came 50 years and a day after the Yom Kippur War of 1973, when Israel was also surprised by a complex Arab attack, leading to huge Israeli losses and soul-searching about the state of the country.

Israel battled on Saturday to repel one of the broadest invasions of its territory in 50 years after Palestinian militants from Gaza launched an enormous and coordinated early-morning assault on southern Israel, infiltrating several Israeli towns and army bases, kidnapping Israeli civilians and soldiers, and firing thousands of rockets toward cities as far away as Jerusalem.

By early evening, the Israeli military said fighting continued in at least five places in southern Israel, around 70 Israelis had been reported dead by emergency medical groups, and Israel had retaliated with huge strikes on Gazan cities. At least 198 Palestinians were killed in either gun battles or airstrikes, the Gazan Health Ministry said.

The Hamas militants behind the attack also took Israelis hostage, the chief spokesman for the Israeli military, Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, said. 

In an assault without recent precedent in its complexity and scale, the militants crossed into Israel by land, sea and air, according to the Israeli military, leading to some of the first pitched battles between large groups of Israeli and Arab forces on Israeli soil in decades. As of early evening there were the two main battles taking place, near the towns of Ofakim and Beeri, Admiral Hagai said.

All told, the Israeli military said that the militants had entered at least 22 Israeli towns, abducting soldiers and civilians, including an older grandmother. Residents of Israeli border towns told broadcasters that gunmen were moving door to door, looking for civilians. Unverified footage appeared to show Palestinian fighters transporting captured Israeli civilians and bodies through the strip.

‚ÄúWe are at war and we will win it,‚Äù Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said in a televised statement, announcing a call-up of Israeli military reservists.

Calamitous Flood in India Shows the Dangers Lurking in Melting Glaciers

At least 26 people were killed in the northeastern Indian state of Sikkim, and another 142 are missing after a glacial lake‚Äôs overflow swept through the tiny Himalayan region. But as much as the disaster was a shock, it was hardly a surprise. An academic paper published four years earlier predicted just such a sequence of events in harrowing detail.

Scientists call this kind of disaster a ‚Äúglacial lake outburst flood,‚Äù or GLOF. The Himalayas are full of potential GLOFs, as many as 7,500 of them, and Sikkim may be home to 10% of the total, with about 25 assessed as high-risk. As deadly as GLOFs are, they can be predicted. And they are predicted to get worse.

Armita Geravand, 16, her short black hair uncovered, entered a subway car in Tehran early Sunday on her way to school. Minutes later, she was dragged out unconscious and laid on the train platform. After surviving more than three decades of on-and-off war and pressure from big outside powers to give up, or at least narrow, its ambitions as a separate country with its own president, army, flag and government, the Republic of Artsakh, within the internationally recognized borders of Azerbaijan, collapsed almost overnight.

Tens of thousands died fighting for or against it, destroying the careers of two presidents ‚Äî one Armenian, one Azerbaijani ‚Äî and tormenting a generation of American, Russian and European diplomats pushing stillborn peace plans. It outlasted six U.S. presidents.

But the self-declared state in the mountainous enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh ‚Äî recognized by no other country ‚Äî vanished so quickly last week that its ethnic Armenian population, driven by fears of ethnic cleansing by a triumphant Azerbaijan, had only minutes to pack before abandoning their homes and joining an exodus.

Michael Bock patrols the city of Portland, Oregon, on behalf of Echelon Protective Services, in his family‚Äôs 2006 minivan. Without the benefit of lights or a siren, he rolls down his window to cajole people into behaving, using a mixture of charm, intimidation, commiseration and free cigarettes.

In many of America‚Äôs overwhelmed downtowns, private security guards like Bock have become the solution of last resort.

In Portland, a record-breaking number of daily emergencies has strained every part of the system: hold times for 911 calls have quintupled since 2019; the average police response time has slowed to nearly an hour; firefighters work overtime, handling more overdoses than actual fires; and each week there is a shortage of ambulances left to respond to hundreds of medical emergencies.
 
Most major U.S. cities now have at least three times the number of security guards on the street as sworn police officers, even though guards typically operate with minimal oversight, less training and little power to enforce the law.

Lise Meitner‚Äôs identity ‚Äî Jewish and a woman ‚Äî prevented her from winning a Nobel Prize and sharing credit for discovering the process that enabled the creation of the atomic bomb, according to newly translated documents.

Long Overlooked, This Hungarian Scientist Helped Shield the World From the Coronavirus

Katalin Karik√≥ grew up in Hungary, daughter of a butcher. She decided she wanted to be a scientist, although she had never met one. She moved to the U.S. in her 20s, and for decades never found a permanent position or earned more than $60,000 a year.

Now Karik√≥, 66, has emerged as one of the heroes of Covid-19 vaccine development. Her work, with her close collaborator, Dr. Drew Weissman of the University of Pennsylvania, laid the foundation for the stunningly successful vaccines made by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna. If you follow the winding roads to Mountain View, Arkansas, home of the Ozark Folk Center, you‚Äôll be rewarded with the sounds of fiddles, banjos and guitars, and, if you don‚Äôt have one already, a passion for music. The center, which turned 50 this year, is singular among the state‚Äôs 52 state parks in that its draw is not landscape and nature. 

‚ÄúOur resource here is the people,‚Äù said Keith Symanowitz, the park‚Äôs promotions director. ‚ÄúOur mission here is to perpetuate, present and promote the Ozark way of life.‚Äù The staff does so by giving the people of the region, which is rural and largely white, a place to do the things they‚Äôve always done ‚Äî and visitors can watch and even try those things themselves: making quilts, brooms, knives and home remedies; carving wood, forging iron, tanning and shaping leather; weaving and dyeing fabric.

Though Mountain View‚Äôs economy depends to a large extent on tourism, the place is authentic. People there are living their lives as they always have, not because they think you will find it enchanting, but because that is what they do and they like doing it. 

Tap the link in our bio to visit the town with music in its heart. Photos and video by @houstoncofield

Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced on Sunday night that he has chosen Laphonza Butler, the president of Emily‚Äôs List and a former labor leader, to fill the vacancy left in the Senate by the death of Dianne Feinstein.

Butler has been a fixture in California politics for nearly 15 years as a former leader of the state‚Äôs largest labor union and an adviser to Vice President Kamala Harris. In 2021, she became the first Black woman to take the helm at Emily‚Äôs List, the fund-raising powerhouse dedicated to electing female candidates and supporters of reproductive rights. A Canadian man was charged with aiding 14 suicides, including that of Ashtyn Prosser, who died one month before his 20th birthday. The man, Kenneth Law, is accused of operating a group of businesses that shipped about 1,200 packages of toxic salt to people in 40 countries, fulfilling orders placed on his website.

Investigators said that Law had shipped 160 packages in Canada; he has been charged by multiple police agencies in Ontario with counseling or aiding suicide in connection with the 14 deaths. The victims were between 16 and 36 years old.

Britain is investigating the deaths of 88 of the 272 people there who purchased salts from Law‚Äôs website, a spokesman for the National Crime Agency in Britain said in an email.

New York Attorney General Letitia James plans to call former President Donald Trump and three of his children to the witness stand in their upcoming civil fraud trial that begins today.

On today's #FrontPage: Lawmakers on Capitol Hill were able to avert a government shutdown for now, but the intense battle over federal spending hasn‚Äôt cooled, the Supreme Court opens its term with justices' nerves still somewhat frayed, and more.

‚Å†
Justice Sonia Sotomayor seems to have lost respect for her colleagues on the Supreme Court ‚Äî literally.‚Å†
‚Å†
In several of her major dissenting opinions last term, Justice Sotomayor dropped the usual decorum, in which justices write that they ‚Äúrespectfully dissent,‚Äù and instead flatly declared, ‚ÄúI dissent.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Court observers said it‚Äôs a sign of growing frustration from Justice Sotomayor and the high court‚Äôs two other Democratic-appointed members, who are limited in their ability to prevail on the big questions of law that are reaching the court with increasing frequency.

Three centuries ago, hysteria swept Salem, Mass., and residents accused about 200 people of witchcraft. This month, local resentment toward witches is brewing again.‚Å†
‚Å†
One million tourists, many sporting pointy black hats, layers of mascara and long capes, were expected to course through this city‚Äôs historic downtown in October to visit cemeteries, haunted houses and witch museums. Traffic is choked. Sidewalks are jammed. ‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hellish,‚Äù said Bri Chisholm, a social worker who has lived in Salem all her life. ‚ÄúLast night, we walked a half mile in the pouring rain with our groceries in brown paper bags because we couldn‚Äôt park anywhere.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Salem‚Äôs streets are narrow and crooked. The front doors of its centuries-old homes swing open onto skinny sidewalks designed for austere Puritans. On a recent Sunday, they were packed with out-of-state tourists, many of them munching candy corn. On Saturday night, Salem‚Äôs mayor cautioned people about driving in. (‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt make it through,‚Äù he wrote on social media, suggesting trains.)‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúSalem Haunted Happenings,‚Äù as locals call the Halloween festivities, is bigger than ever. When pandemic lockdowns lifted, what had been a mostly regional tourist attraction went national, according to the tourism department. Cellphone data shows visitors coming from as far away as Ohio, Texas and California.‚Å†
‚Å†
The hordes inject millions of dollars into the local economy. Homes rent out for $2,000 a night. Hotels book up a year in advance.‚Å†
‚Å†
Last year, Stacia Cooper, director of a local tourism board, scolded her high-school-age son when he spent $300 on an 8-foot Sasquatch costume. So far this fall, he has made more than $1,000 posing with tourists.‚Å†

When Julia Park Tracey her husband, Patrick Tracey, bought a home in Grass Valley, Calif., pictured here, the owner didn‚Äôt disclose on any paperwork that the house was haunted. ‚Å†
‚Å†
But Julia says the owner told them it was haunted informally and jokingly, saying things like, ‚ÄúOf course it‚Äôs haunted; it‚Äôs an old house.‚Äù Then, the owner died on the day she was moving out of the home.‚Å†
‚Å†
As soon as the couple moved in, Julia says coins started showing up. Shiny pennies turned up for several years where she had already scoured. ‚ÄúIt was like she came back every night and seeded the ground with pennies,‚Äù Julia says. ‚ÄúIt was weird. She didn‚Äôt want to leave‚Ä¶and by God, she didn‚Äôt.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
The rules surrounding disclosure in the sale of a supposedly haunted house have a few surprises. In Massachusetts, New Jersey and Minnesota, a supposed haunting is explicitly listed in disclosure rules as a non-material fact that does not need to be disclosed to potential buyers. New York is the fourth state that overtly addresses hauntings. In all states, neither seller nor agent can misrepresent the home‚Äôs history if they are asked.‚Å†
‚Å†
According to data compiled by All Star Home, only 24% of those surveyed say they would buy a haunted house.‚Å†
‚Å†
Florida real-estate agent Wes Pearce doesn‚Äôt believe in ghosts and thinks the current rules about disclosure are fine. ‚ÄúThese claims are impossible to prove,‚Äù he says, ‚Äúand such subjective claims could unfairly tarnish perfectly good properties.‚Äù‚Å†

‚ÄúFriends‚Äù was the sitcom that defined us, and Matthew Perry‚Äôs Chandler Bing was its defining character, writes Kyle Smith, the Journal‚Äôs film critic, for @wsjopinion.

Chandler was nearly Perry‚Äôs double: a tortured loner for whom cynicism was body armor. He died prematurely on Saturday, at 54.

Flip, sarcastic and allergic to attachment, Perry typified the Gen X sensibility in his 10 years as Chandler. Our age cohort (I was born in 1966, Perry three years later) has frequently been dismissed as nondescript, but what is special about us has become apparent in retrospect. We were the last generation to grow up predigital, meaning spoken conversation was our default means of communication. We were scarred by divorce, which peaked when we were kids, like no generation before or since. Many of us sought to build replacement families out of pals living close at hand, taking dorm living as our model.

Perry‚Äôs portrayal of Chandler was informed by revealing conversations he had with the show‚Äôs writers. Unlike Matt LeBlanc‚Äôs Joey Tribbiani (a caricature of a brainless actor) and David Schwimmer‚Äôs Ross Geller (painfully earnest and therefore not typical of a generation that venerates irony), Chandler was the perpetual wry observer, wisecracking from a distance.

His cynicism and sarcasm were a reflection of our own outlook on life.

Read more at the link in @wsjopinion‚Äôs bio.

You like your job. You‚Äôre over everything else that comes with it.‚Å†
‚Å†

Cannabis companies have promoted their products as helpful for anxiety, making for a potentially lucrative market. Anxious consumers have turned to weed and edibles for relief as treatments for their ailments have become harder to find. The number of available and affordable therapists badly lags demand and traditional medications don‚Äôt work for everyone.‚Å†
‚Å†
Driving both users‚Äô and businesses‚Äô hopes is a belief that pot can make us less anxious. Yet little independent scientific evidence shows that cannabis is an effective treatment for anxiety problems, and some studies have found it can worsen symptoms. Researchers say this is particularly true for products high in THC, the substance responsible for marijuana‚Äôs intoxicating effects.‚Å†
‚Å†
Cannabis use was significantly associated with increased odds of developing anxiety conditions, according to a review of research published in 2020 in the Canadian Journal of Psychiatry. Recent cannabis use was associated with more severe symptoms in people with anxiety and mood disorders, according to another review published in 2018 in the Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. ‚Å†
‚Å†
In some surveys, cannabis users have reported that they have felt relief from anxiety symptoms after consuming cannabis. ‚Å†
‚Å†
A survey last year found that nearly two-thirds of people said they would prefer to use cannabis rather than pharmaceuticals to treat a medical issue, according to the survey conducted by the Harris Poll on behalf of cannabis company Curaleaf of almost 2,000 adults who were at least 21 years old. And among the 54% of respondents who said they had ever used cannabis, 41% of them said they consumed cannabis to reduce anxiety.‚Å†
‚Å†
Earlier bets on selling legal pot as a salve for pain and post-traumatic stress disorder haven‚Äôt proved as profitable as hoped. ‚Å†
‚Å†

Every year around this time, Anchorage, Alaska, prepares for the freezing-cold winter by getting snowplows and deicing equipment ready. It also has to get hundreds of homeless people off the streets.‚Å†
‚Å†
The number of Anchorage residents without homes grew nearly 60% between 2019 and 2023 to an estimated 1,760. That is more than bigger cities including Indianapolis; Louisville, Ky.; Baltimore, and Oklahoma City, based on point-in-time counts conducted once each year.‚Å†
‚Å†
Allowing people to stay on the streets means likely injury or death in a city that experiences an average of 20 days annually below zero degrees Fahrenheit. But an arena used to house those without homes the past three winters was recently closed, and political infighting killed plans to build a large new shelter. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Now, as part of a plan approved just a month before bitterly cold temperatures typically arrive in mid-November, aid workers are scrambling to get an estimated 700 people living outdoors into a network of hotel rooms and other makeshift facilities. Some are being offered one-way tickets to the Lower 48 states.‚Å†
‚Å†
Cold weather is a growing public-health threat as more people live on the streets nationwide. Nationally, about 700 homeless people a year die from exposure to the cold, according to the National Coalition for the Homeless, a nonprofit group. In Anchorage, a record 43 people have died from cold and other causes outdoors so far this year, compared with six in all of 2019.‚Å†
‚Å†
This city of 288,000 is home to 40% of Alaska‚Äôs population of 730,000, but nearly 70% of the homeless population in this year‚Äôs point-in-time count. Across the U.S., such one-time tallies are widely acknowledged to undercount the total number of homeless people in an area.‚Å†
‚Å†

‚Å†
Peggy and John Middleton, 68 and 70, are carrying on a family tradition of exploring the U.S. with a travel trailer for months at a time.‚Å†

Peggy‚Äôs parents owned several RVs in the 1970s and ‚Äô80s, spending their summers on the roads of the U.S. and Canada. About 20 years ago, they offered Peggy their 1968 Airstream Globetrotter. ‚Å†

About six years ago the Springfield, Mo., retired nurses began restoring the Airstream in their spare time, spending about $20,000 to make it functional again, Peggy said. A short-term relocation to Denver in 2021 allowed for camping trips around the West while fine-tuning their RV skills.‚Å†

One of the few indoor public spaces open to all comers, libraries are now the scene for all that ails a public scarred by the pandemic and an opioid epidemic.‚Å†
‚Å†
For staff, that means reversing overdoses in bathrooms, confronting patrons watching pornography or defending against people brandishing guns. Some people come to the library to sleep, get warm or use the bathroom. Others are looking for jobs, housing or just somewhere safe to read.‚Å†
‚Å†
Librarians are helping more patrons in crisis, and many cities are hiring social workers to help them. About two-thirds of nearly 600 library workers surveyed by Urban Librarians Unite in 2022 said they had experienced violent or aggressive behavior from patrons.‚Å†
‚Å†
Six years ago, fewer than two dozen libraries in North America employed full-time social workers, said Sarah Johnson, a licensed social worker and adjunct lecturer at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign. Today, more than 100 employ social workers, and more have social-work interns, she said.‚Å†
‚Å†
The social-work program at the Cabell County Public Library in Huntington, W.Va., is one of the country‚Äôs oldest, dating to the 1970s. On the third floor, social workers help patrons with substance-use disorder find treatment centers and victims of domestic violence find safe havens. They assist patrons with sorting out utility bills, bus tickets and housing.‚Å†
‚Å†
A rise in methamphetamine in Huntington‚Äôs illicit drug supply has worsened some people‚Äôs mental distress. City agencies are so overburdened that it can take a month to get a person who is struggling on the streets involuntarily committed at a hospital. The library is in danger of losing a third of its budget next year.‚Å†
‚Å†

‚Å†
The 19-year-old dropped out of the Georgia Institute of Technology in May to focus full time on his artificial-intelligence startup, Automorphic. He is among a swarm of teenagers and 20-somethings leaving college behind to capitalize on a gold rush in AI.‚Å†

The debut of ChatGPT and Bard brought the faraway promises of conversational, helpful AI closer to reality, setting off a rush of investment and new companies that automate tasks and transform work. More than 25% of American startup investments have gone to AI companies so far this year, according to Crunchbase, an industry tracker.‚Å†
‚Å†
The size of the market for generative-AI applications‚Äî$43 billion for enterprise-technology AI alone this year, according to PitchBook‚Äîand the rapid pace of development have young founders ditching class and jumping in.‚Å†
‚Å†
Numbers of dropouts-turned-founders aren‚Äôt tracked, but several founders accepted to this summer‚Äôs cohort by Y Combinator, a prominent startup accelerator program, left campus for their companies.‚Å†

Investors generally praise dropouts‚Äô hustle but note that a great many of the ventures will fizzle out. Many students are up for experimenting and failing because many don‚Äôt have mortgages or children yet, says Jeffrey Sohl, who leads the Center for Venture Research at the University of New Hampshire as well as a student angel-investment fund.‚Å†

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the wonder of youth. You‚Äôve got to love them,‚Äù says Sohl. Still, he adds, ‚ÄúNot all of them can change the world.‚Äù‚Å†

For decades, downtown office districts across the U.S. powered local economies, generating commerce, tax revenue and an aggregation of ambition, talent and disposable income. Now, many cities riddled with half-empty office buildings are hoping to survive the new remote-work era without bulldozing swaths of downtown and starting from scratch.‚Å†
‚Å†
American downtowns instead face the biggest urban makeover in 50 years, experts say. It's a turning point similar to when factories disappeared from city centers during the 20th century‚Äôs workplace transformation and left steel-and-glass office towers as the primary economic engines.‚Å†
‚Å†
Even optimists estimate it will take years and cost billions to complete the large-scale changes to usher central-city office districts into a new role‚Äîbusy neighborhoods where people live, work, raise families and find entertainment.‚Å†
‚Å†
Some cities have been pushing to remake their downtown districts for years and know the many obstacles: Few office buildings can be converted to housing. Downtowns don‚Äôt easily accommodate family life. Crime fears keep people in the suburbs. No one wants to be downtown if nobody else is.‚Å†
‚Å†
Minneapolis, which has seen lonely sidewalks and empty storefronts in its downtown, is considering a pedestrian-only zone and has offered tax breaks to convert offices to apartments. But office building renovations are tough even under the best conditions. Demolitions are costly, developers often have to buy out office leaseholders, and interest rates are high.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to have to work on creating spaces down there that are appealing to people on weekends,‚Äù said George Sherman, a longtime Minneapolis developer who is trying to convert downtown offices to apartments. ‚ÄúRight now, that‚Äôs hard to imagine. But part of our job is to imagine them 10 years out.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†

One of the most durable forces shaping the U.S. electorate is that voters tend to lean more Republican as they age.‚Å†
‚Å†
But it also matters where they begin on the political spectrum, and there are indications that millennials and the oldest members of Generation Z started out more liberal than prior generations. That has made them a crucial base of support for Democrats, even as some other groups of voters have moved away from the party.‚Å†
‚Å†
Gaining assets and income pushes voters toward conservative fiscal policies, such as lower taxes, that allow them to keep more of their money, researchers say. As Americans move from midlife to retirement, they are more likely to favor stability over change, and less likely to back liberal policies that upset the social order.‚Å†
‚Å†
This rightward shift is likely to affect who wins elections in 2024 and the years beyond. One in six Americans is age 65 or over, up from one in eight a decade prior, according to the most recent decennial census. A slump in births that started in 2008 will eventually give way to a smaller pool of new, young voters.‚Å†
‚Å†
On its face, the shift bodes well for Republicans. Yet its effects have been muted by the size and liberal bent of millennials now approaching middle age, and the more solidly blue partisanship of Gen Z voters just entering the electorate.‚Å†
‚Å†

When Leslie Hendeles walked into his neighborhood drugstore last week and learned that a common cold medicine was being pulled off the shelves, he was stunned. The news affirmed a decadeslong quest to steer consumers away from a drug that he long-believed didn‚Äôt work.‚Å†
‚Å†
Hendeles, a retired professor, with his friend, fellow pharmacist and University of Florida professor Randy Hatton, have spent nearly 20 years following the science of phenylephrine, an ingredient in more than 200 over-the-counter decongestants.‚Å†
‚Å†
Last month, following a petition from Hatton and Hendeles, an advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration weighed studies examining oral phenylephrine‚Äôs power to unblock sinuses and clear stuffy noses, and unanimously determined that it wasn‚Äôt effective.‚Å†
‚Å†
Last week CVS, one of the nation‚Äôs biggest pharmacies, told WSJ that certain medicines that list phenylephrine as their only active ingredient were being pulled from shelves for good.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúPharmacists were telling us, this doesn‚Äôt work,‚Äù Hatton said. Over two decades the duo amassed evidence that backed up their conviction, and drew attention to the issue from lawmakers, health agencies, pharmacies and their customers.‚Å†
‚Å†
Approved for use nearly a century ago, phenylephrine is listed as an ingredient in pills, syrups and liquids such as Advil Sinus Congestion & Pain, Flonase Headache & Allergy Relief, and DayQuil Cold & Flu.‚Å†
‚Å†
But studies over the years have shown that it is not more effective to clear nasal congestion than a placebo when taken orally. Scientists believe that is partly because almost all of it is inactivated in the gut and liver before it reaches the bloodstream.‚Å†
‚Å†

More than a year after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, one thing seems clear: New state bans have done little so far to deter women from obtaining abortions. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Data released Tuesday shows the number of abortions ticked up slightly in the year following the high court‚Äôs Dobbs v. Jackson Women‚Äôs Health Organization decision. That ruling, from June 2022, ended federal protections for the procedure, and paved the way for some 16 states to ban many or most abortions. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The data indicate that abortion providers, funders and others have adapted quickly to a legal landscape that has changed profoundly. Access has been cut off throughout much of the South, and demand has surged in states in which abortion is still legal. Many providers there have had to significantly increase capacity. ‚Å†
‚Å†
In the new study, WeCount, an abortion-data project sponsored by the Society of Family Planning, which supports abortion rights, found that nationwide there were 183 more monthly abortions on average in the 12-month period following the Dobbs decision compared with the monthly average prior to the decision. ‚Å†
‚Å†
While it has become much harder since the end of Roe to obtain an abortion in states with newly enacted bans, it actually appears to have become easier in many other states, thanks to increased attention and resources. Abortion funds, nonprofits that help finance abortions and logistics associated with them, have raised millions to help lower-income women pay for procedures and travel, while new clinics have opened in states such as Illinois and New Mexico that have become major destinations for women traveling from other states. ‚Å†
‚Å†

‚ÄúEver since I was a boy, I knew everything would be OK if I could just get to America.‚Äù ‚Å†
‚Å†
Ghanaian refugee John Ekow boarded a vessel in July in the Ivory Coast with the prospect of making landfall in the U.S. There was just one problem: the ship was bound for Brazil.‚Å†
‚Å†
Brazilian officials have been bedeviled by a new phenomenon: a small but growing number of African migrants who completed a perilous 2,000-mile journey from West Africa after sneaking onto cargo ships they believed were actually headed for Europe or the U.S.‚Å†
‚Å†
Some African arrivals say criminal gangs and fishermen in West Africa tricked them into boarding the wrong ships, charging a small fee to hoist them aboard, including onto narrow platforms behind the ship‚Äôs rudder, according to researchers and authorities studying clandestine immigration. ‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI was gutted,‚Äù Ekow said, describing the moment the ship‚Äôs captain told him he was not in the U.S. but in Macap√°, Brazil, where the Atlantic meets the Amazon River.‚Å†
‚Å†
The 24-year-old and a friend boarded the ship in Abidjan with the help of a local fisherman. During the trip the men huddled together for warmth, rationing out tins of sardines and a bottled mush of cassava flour and water. By the third day, the food was gone. By the fifth, they ran out of water.‚Å†
‚Å†
On the seventh day, the ship suddenly slowed down. Police officers at the port of Macap√° said they could either go back to Africa or stay in Brazil and file for asylum, Ekow said. Both opted for the latter. His friend, who had brought a fistful of dollars with him, told Ekow he was going to try and trudge to the U.S.‚Å†
‚Å†
A total of 234 migrants arrived in Brazil as stowaways between 2006 and 2017, almost exclusively from Africa, hidden in ships that docked in at least 15 different states along Brazil‚Äôs almost 5,000-mile coastline, according to the latest available data from the country‚Äôs navy. ‚Å†

With the Capitol in chaos and the speaker‚Äôs position going on its third week of vacancy, Rep. Matt Gaetz surveyed the consequences of his actions and declared he had no regrets.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI have extreme confidence,‚Äù the Florida Republican said in an interview from his Capitol Hill office, ‚Äúthat we will have an upgrade at the position.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
The House has had no speaker since Gaetz made a motion to vacate the position, then joined on Oct. 3 with seven other Republicans and 208 Democrats to oust Rep. Kevin McCarthy (R., Calif.) from the role. Rep. Jim Jordan, the archconservative Ohio Republican whom Gaetz calls a mentor, this week failed on three ballots to secure the majority of the body‚Äôs votes, losing support on each roll call and then bowing out of the race Friday afternoon. No one else seems to have a clear path to 217 GOP votes for the position. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Many of his colleagues blame Gaetz for the paralysis and acrimony that have ensued. When Gaetz rose to speak in a closed-door party meeting on Thursday, McCarthy told him to ‚Äúsit your ass down,‚Äù and another Republican, Rep. Mike Bost of Illinois, cursed and lunged at Gaetz.‚Å†
‚Å†
Asked about the encounter afterward, McCarthy told reporters, ‚ÄúListen, the whole country, I think, would scream at Matt Gaetz right now.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
The upheavals that have racked the House GOP since January are less a reflection of any coherent faction than one man‚Äôs singular will. It was Gaetz who took it upon himself to block McCarthy from the speakership in January, joining with 19 others to deny him a majority until he agreed to crippling concessions. One of those was the ability for a single member to bring the motion to vacate, which Gaetz then deployed to remove McCarthy this month.‚Å†
‚Å†
While critics accuse Gaetz of attention-mongering, he insists he is about outcomes, not headlines. He says he has received a flood of approving feedback from conservatives across the country.‚Å†

U.S. public opinion is rallying behind Israel as it responds to the deadly attacks on its citizens by Hamas, the Islamist militant group, but the American appetite for a role in the war is limited, a new WSJ/Ipsos poll finds.‚Å†

Some 42% in the survey said the U.S. should side with Israel, a record high dating to 2002, while 3% said the U.S. should take the Palestinians‚Äô side. At the same time, the survey found Americans reluctant to become engaged in the region. Some 52% said the U.S. shouldn‚Äôt back either Israel or the Palestinians in their long-running conflict. If you want to live to your 100th birthday, healthy habits can only get you so far.‚Å†
‚Å†
Research is making clearer the role that genes play in living to very old age. Habits like getting enough sleep, exercising and eating a healthy diet can help you stave off disease and live longer, yet when it comes to living beyond 90, genetics start to play a trump card, say researchers who study aging.‚Å†
‚Å†
About 25% of your ability to live to 90 is determined by genetics, says Dr. Thomas Perls, a professor of medicine at Boston University who leads the New England Centenarian Study. By age 100, it‚Äôs roughly 50% genetic, he estimates, and by around 106, it‚Äôs 75%.‚Å†
‚Å†
Centenarians make up a growing share of the U.S. population. There are about 109,000 centenarians living in the country in 2023, according to Census Bureau projections, up from about 65,000 10 years ago, thanks in part to decades of advances in medicine and public health.‚Å†
‚Å†
Knowing what enables some people to live very long lives has consequences for the rest of us. Ongoing research into very old age may help provide insight that could eventually be used to develop drugs or identify lifestyle changes to help people live healthier for longer, says Dr. James Kirkland, president of the American Federation for Aging Research.‚Å†
‚Å†
Perls estimates that roughly 20% of the population has the genetic makeup that could get them to 100 if they also make consistent healthy choices.‚Å†

A renewed interest in self-reliance is driving city dwellers and suburbanites to stock their homes and cars for emergencies, owners of disaster-preparedness businesses say. For Judy‚Äîwhose bright-orange disaster packs start at $195‚Äîyear-over-year sales quadrupled in June, when wildfire smoke blanketed the Northeast. U.S. Department of Agriculture budget analyst Wayne Connelly braced for his boss to discover his office had been taken over by historical artifacts. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Connelly had quietly started amassing materials from the agency‚Äôs 160-plus-year history to revive a museum that had closed more than a century ago. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Its new location: Connelly‚Äôs office and that of his remotely working boss. His supervisor said he didn‚Äôt mind having his former desk occupied by an exhibit on botanical explorers, among others, earlier this year.‚Å†
‚Å†
Around seven months ago, Connelly, shown here, hung a sign in the hallway proclaiming ‚ÄúMuseum‚Äù in antique-looking font, inviting passersby to stop by his warren of rooms crammed with artifacts, photos, typed placards explaining the historical significance, framed newspaper articles and colorful prints covering every inch of available wall and desktop.‚Å†
‚Å†
At the time it was built in the 1930s, the USDA‚Äôs South Building was believed to be the largest office building in the world, with 4,500 rooms, 7 miles of corridors, 12 million bricks and 11,000 miles of structural steel, according to the General Services Administration. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Connelly, a 35-year veteran of the agency, wasn‚Äôt always combing through that labyrinth looking for historical finds. But during the pandemic, he returned to the office earlier than many others and began walking the empty halls. ‚Å†
‚Å†
He began doing more research into the history of the agency, founded in 1862 by then-President Abraham Lincoln to deepen agricultural research and disseminate information at a time when about half of all Americans lived on farms. ‚Å†
‚Å†
For roughly two years, Connelly has been on a mission to track down every interesting historical item still lurking in the thousands of rooms that make up the U.S. Agriculture Department. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The museum‚Äôs latest challenge is access. For now, visitors can only enter with a USDA employee, given the location.‚Å†

A potential blockbuster weight-loss drug still years away from U.S. regulatory approval is already being sold online, another example of a thriving gray market for unapproved weight-loss medications, according to a WSJ review.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Journal found hundreds of merchants offering the new drug, which is being developed by Eli Lilly and is called retatrutide. Most appear to be Chinese sellers shipping directly to U.S. consumers from sites such as Made-in-China.com. Some of the sites, including ones that appear to be based in the U.S., have marketed their products via posts on Facebook, LinkedIn and Reddit. A handful have run paid ads on Instagram and Google. A fitness influencer has offered it for sale via his newsletter.‚Å†
‚Å†
Excitement over retatrutide jumped in June when Lilly reported Phase 2 trial results that showed the drug led to an average weight loss of up to 24% over 48 weeks. That could prove better than Lilly‚Äôs already-approved drug Mounjaro.‚Å†
‚Å†
In August, the Journal reported that more than 50 websites were selling knockoff semaglutide and tirzepatide, the active ingredients in Ozempic and Mounjaro respectively. The Food and Drug Administration issued warning letters to two websites for ‚Äúunlawful sale of unapproved and misbranded drugs‚Äù after the Journal‚Äôs article. One, GorillaHealing.com, no longer lists those two drugs on its website, but does offer retatrutide. Last week, three days after the warning letter was posted publicly, the top result in a Google search for ‚Äúbuy retatrutide‚Äù was a GorillaHealing.com ad.‚Å†
‚Å†
GorillaHealing.com didn‚Äôt respond to a request for comment. Meta Platforms, which owns Facebook and Instagram, as well as Google, LinkedIn and Reddit all said in statements that they removed advertisements or user posts that were flagged by the Journal, each citing internal policies.‚Å†
‚Å†
In a statement, the FDA said it would continue to investigate reports of suspect counterfeit drugs to determine the public health risks and the appropriate regulatory response. ‚Å†

The highest mortgage rates in 23 years are dragging down home sales to their lowest levels since the subprime crisis period.‚Å†
‚Å†
Sales of previously owned homes in 2023 are expected to dwindle to a rate not seen since at least 2011, when the U.S. population was smaller and the country was still recovering from one of the worst housing crises ever, according to many economist forecasts.‚Å†
‚Å†
Chen Zhao, economics research lead at real-estate brokerage Redfin, estimated that total existing-home sales in 2023 would amount to around 4.1 million, which would mark the smallest number of sales since about 2008, the year that Lehman Brothers collapsed and sparked the global financial crisis. Zhao said sales are unlikely to pick up much next year, with mortgage rates likely to remain at elevated levels. ‚Å†
‚Å†
This year‚Äôs housing slowdown is very different from the previous one, after the housing bubble of the early 2000s burst. Back then, the economy entered a deep recession and millions of people lost their homes to foreclosure. ‚Å†
‚Å†
This time around, home sales have been slowing for more than a year because of rising borrowing costs, record-high home prices and a very limited inventory of homes for sale. ‚Å†
‚Å†
If existing-home sales for the full year end up even lower than expected at fewer than four million, that would mark the first drop below that level since 1995, according to the National Association of Realtors. ‚Å†

The records show Remington signed a deal in 2009 with videogame publisher Activision Blizzard to put a new weapon called the Adaptive Combat Rifle, or ACR, in its 2009 release ‚ÄúCall of Duty: Modern Warfare 2.‚Äù Remington hoped to sell civilian and military versions of the ACR, a modular rifle that uses design elements from several other weapons including the AR-15. ‚Å†

An accounting career, once a launchpad into the upper middle class for hundreds of thousands of Americans, is no longer paying off.‚Å†

Some of the nation‚Äôs largest college accounting programs, such as Florida Atlantic University and the University of Maryland, have seen their enrollment or number of undergraduate majors decline by double-digit percentages in recent years. That has led to even greater workloads for existing accountants, and more than 300,000 have left the profession between 2019 and 2022, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.‚Å†

‚ÄúWe introduced the shame for people for whom diet and exercise wasn‚Äôt enough,‚Äù she said at a recent event, seated next to the company‚Äôs investor, board director and the most famous dieter in America, Oprah Winfrey.‚Å†
‚Å†
For decades, WeightWatchers told the world that weight loss came through sheer willpower‚Äî‚Äúchoice, not chance,‚Äù as its founder, Jean Nidetch, said in the 1960s. Now, thanks to new drugs like Ozempic, Sistani is rejecting that blame-the-dieter approach in favor of the view that obesity is an illness‚Äîone her company can help cure.‚Å†
‚Å†
The promise that a doctor‚Äôs prescription can eliminate extra weight for good has touched off a seismic moment in global health, and compelled WeightWatchers to undergo its most radical change yet.‚Å†
‚Å†
So that it could prescribe weight-loss drugs, the company paid $106 million to acquire telehealth company Sequence. But Sistani‚Äôs biggest change has been cultural, as WeightWatchers wades into a fraught debate: Whose fault is it if you‚Äôre fat? And were those decades of WeightWatchers‚Äô count-your-points plans liberating or stigmatizing for millions of customers? WeightWatchers has opted to apologize for much of what made it iconic.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe want to be the first to say where we got it wrong,‚Äù Sistani said. ‚Å†

Even as 5G mobile networks begin to expand in India, about half of the country‚Äôs 1.4 billion people remain disconnected from the Internet. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Billionaire Mukesh Ambani is betting a new web-enabled mobile phone that costs about $12 can change that and win yet more customers for his dominant wireless-network provider.‚Å†

‚Å†
While the device isn‚Äôt 5G-capable, it offers 4G speeds, meaning it can stream music and video via pre-installed apps from Reliance Jio‚Äôs services. The phone can also be used to make digital payments, a practice that has boomed in India in recent years.‚Å†
‚Å†
Many Indians who are online access the Internet via smartphones. But a smartphone in India typically costs more than $250, far out of reach for millions of people who make just a few dollars a day. ‚Å†
‚Å†
After paying $12 for Reliance Jio‚Äôs new device, customers pay about $1.50 a month for unlimited voice calls and 14 gigabytes of data, a lower rate than services from rival carriers.‚Å†
‚Å†
The initial one million units the company released appear to be selling well so far, says Tarun Pathak, director at India-based Counterpoint Research. ‚ÄúHowever, we believe that it is still a long road ahead for Jio to capture over 200 million 2G users,‚Äù he says, given challenges such as limited battery life and small screen size.‚Å†

One day, you wake up, and the power is out. You try to get information on your phone, and you have no internet access. Gradually you discover millions of people across the U.S. are in the same situation‚Äìone that will bring months or years of rebuilding. A gigantic solar storm has hit Earth. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The odds are low that in any given year a storm big enough to cause effects this widespread will happen. And the severity of those impacts will depend on many factors, including the state of our planet‚Äôs magnetic field on that day. But it‚Äôs a near certainty that some form of this catastrophe will happen someday, says Ian Cohen, a chief scientist who studies heliophysics at the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory.‚Å†
‚Å†
To get ahead of this threat, a loose federation of U.S. and international government agencies, and hundreds of scientists affiliated with those bodies, have begun working on how to make predictions about what our Sun might do. And a small but growing cadre of scientists argue that artificial intelligence will be an essential component of efforts to give us advance notice of such a storm.‚Å†
‚Å†
The most dangerous of these solar storms is known as a coronal mass ejection, or CME, when a gargantuan blob of charged particles is catapulted from the Sun‚Äôs atmosphere by rapidly shifting magnetic fields, at speeds in excess of 8,000 times that of sound. These happen often, but we‚Äôre rarely aware of them because they only affect us when they happen to strike earth.‚Å†
‚Å†
Satellites that orbit high above Earth in so-called geostationary orbit would be the first to feel the effects. In theory, they can be incapacitated by ‚Äúkiller electrons‚Äù more common during certain kinds of solar storms. The electrons can penetrate satellites, and the resulting charge can build up, damaging electronics. Losing these satellites could cause worldwide disruption of GPS services.‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.‚Å†
‚Å†

After a historic run-up in prices, the luxury rental market in the Miami area is seeing a significant slowdown. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Although rents are still generally higher than they were prepandemic, local real-estate agents said the velocity of people moving to Miami has slowed and there are fewer people willing to overpay. Meanwhile, newly built apartments are adding thousands of rental units to the market, further easing the supply-demand imbalance that has characterized the market over the past few years.‚Å†
‚Å†
In the Miami luxury market, defined as the top 10% of the market, nearly all segments are down from pandemic-era peaks, said local real-estate agent Ana Bozovic, whose firm Analytics.Miami tracks the market. ‚Å†
‚Å†
So far this year, the median monthly rent for a luxury three-bedroom house in Miami-Dade County is $8,500, down 15% from $10,000 last year, she said. For condos, the median monthly rent for a luxury three-bedroom is $8,200, down 8.9% from $9,000 last year.‚Å†
‚Å†
Overall, Miami‚Äôs rental market seems to be cooling faster than other cities nationwide, according to data from listing website Zumper. In September, the median monthly rent for a Miami one-bedroom apartment fell 1.47% to $2,690 from the month before, and 1.96% to $2,500 in Miami Beach, Zumper said. By comparison, the median rent for a one-bedroom nationwide grew 0.1% to $1,511 during the same period.‚Å†
‚Å†
The dip is a sharp change from the frenzied pace of the real-estate market over the past few years, as an influx of people moved to Miami for warm weather and low taxes, driving up real-estate values to historic levels. ‚Å†
‚Å†

As Americans return to the office, and want to keep tabs‚Äîor a tight leash‚Äîon their pets, they‚Äôre using their security cameras and speakers to scold, comfort and manage from afar. ‚Å†

Instead, she advises pet owners to talk to their pets through cameras when they‚Äôre behaving well. ‚Å†

The moment has arrived to recognize that for the adversaries of the free world, killing innocent civilians is the new normal, writes Daniel Henninger for @wsjopinion.

Hamas fighters on the ground explicitly targeted Israeli civilians for killing. Israelis were shot while driving along the street. They were pulled from their homes and killed. Hamas carried out the mass murder of some 260 people at the Tribe of Nova music festival.

Vladimir Putin, a purported friend of Israel, has said little, other than blaming a failure of U.S. policy in the Middle East. No surprise there. What Hamas did to the Israelis is what Putin has been doing to civilians in Ukraine for almost two years.

Since the February 2022 invasion, it is estimated that about 10,000 Ukrainian civilians have been killed. Russia has killed hundreds with missiles fired into residential areas of Ukrainian cities and towns. It has targeted schools, hospitals and food markets.

These civilian deaths‚Äîby Hamas in Israel and Russia in Ukraine‚Äîare not collateral damage from urban warfare. They are part of the war plan, thought out by calm men sitting around a table, in Moscow or Beirut, looking at maps and civilian targets. Crimes against humanity are becoming normalized.

Our adversaries‚ÄîRussia, Iran, China and North Korea‚Äîwill continue the mass killing of civilians and hostage-taking as a strategic policy until the U.S. decisively counters this awful new normal.

Read more at the link in @wsjopinion‚Äôs bio.

America‚Äôs highest office vacancies aren‚Äôt in the East and West Coast cities that have been shedding population and workers. They are in Texas, a thriving Sunbelt state that has been luring companies away from the big coastal cities.‚Å†
‚Å†
Houston, Dallas and Austin top the list of major U.S. cities with the highest office-vacancy rates, according to Moody‚Äôs Analytics. About 25% of their office space wasn‚Äôt leased as of the third quarter. That was more than double New York‚Äôs vacancy rate of 12% and well above San Francisco‚Äôs vacancy rate of 17%.‚Å†
‚Å†
Texas office floors are struggling to find tenants even though the state‚Äôs workers have been more eager to get back to the office than in most other places. According to Kastle Systems, which measures occupancy by counting keycard swipes in 10 major metro areas, Houston, Austin and Dallas have the highest office-return rates.‚Å†
‚Å†
Vacancies are high largely because Texas developers build too much. All three cities experienced a surge in construction in the 1980s, when tax rules favored developers and loose lending created a commercial real-estate bubble. Another construction spurt in the late 1990s aggravated the problem.‚Å†
‚Å†
Texas‚Äô high vacancy rate offers more evidence that the U.S. office market‚Äôs biggest problem hasn‚Äôt been primarily remote work. It is a glut of buildings across the U.S., which has been decades in the making and helps explain why the country has long had much higher vacancy rates than Europe or Asia. Office markets in other booming Sunbelt cities such as Atlanta are also suffering, despite economic growth and job creation.‚Å†

It‚Äôs that magical golden hour on the beach, just before sunset, with everyone smiling and centered and not another soul around. It‚Äôs a perfect photo to put over the fireplace.‚Å†

Only that moment never happened.‚Å†

It was actually midday, there were random strangers in the shot, and there‚Äôs no one image where all the family members are smiling and looking at the camera. ‚ÄúPhoto editing‚Äù has become ‚Äúphoto manipulation.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Fudging things to get an ideal shot isn‚Äôt a new concept, but now this kind of work can be done by anyone, with a few quick phone taps. Google has been at the forefront of democratizing this technological innovation. Its latest Pixel 8 and Pixel 8 Pro models, available Oct. 12, make bending reality a breeze.‚Å†
‚Å†
Among Pixel‚Äôs AI tools is a face swapper called Best Take. It looks at similar shots you‚Äôve taken in succession. In a group photo, you can tap on each face and select another one you like from the series. So you can easily replace a closed-eye, mouth-agape head with one that‚Äôs smiling.‚Å†
‚Å†
Another new tool, Magic Editor, lets you move people around in a photo and delete unwanted objects in the background.‚Å†
‚Å†
Editing family photos seems harmless. But the manipulation itself, once full of visual clues, is now harder to spot and easier to pull off. Some computer scientists are concerned that the rise of artificial-intelligence techniques to alter images means we soon won‚Äôt be able to tell fact from fiction.‚Å†

It was on Arnault‚Äôs wrist.‚Å†

His version was made of the rare metal tantalum. Tantalum gave the watch its gunmetal color, though the metal‚Äôs hardness also meant that the watch took twice as much time to manufacture. This made it ‚Äúinsanely expensive‚Äù when he bought it, Arnault said, though he refused to reveal what he paid.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre only going to make one,‚Äù Arnault said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs it. It‚Äôs the only one.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Two years ago, when he first joined Louis Vuitton‚Äôs watches division as market ing and development director, Louis Vuitton watches ran a wide gamut. They ranged from watches costing hundreds of thousands of dollars to quartz timepieces that sold for around $4,000.‚Å†
‚Å†
Now Arnault has decided to eliminate the entry-level Tambours. His thinking was that instead of producing more affordable collections, Louis Vuitton needed to play in a different class. So the new iteration of the timepiece ranges in price from $18,500 to $52,000, putting it in competition with similar creations from the likes of Audemars Piguet and Vacheron Constantin.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to make a ton of money with this,‚Äù Arnault says of the company‚Äôs strategic about-face. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going to be highly profitable at all, but it‚Äôs really about making sure that we switch the message completely.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†

Palestinian militants on Saturday launched the biggest attack on Israel in years, sending fighters over the border from Gaza and firing thousands of rockets.

Americans who eat their way through European vacations sometimes come home surprised to see a lower number on the scale. The phenomenon has become something of an internet debate, with some people speculating that weight loss on European sojourns points to unhealthy American diets and processed foods.‚Å†
‚Å†
So what‚Äôs the real answer? Alas, there‚Äôs no definitive explanation. You might be surprised (or not!) to find out that research on vacation is scant.‚Å†
‚Å†
Scientists who study nutrition and health say that people who lose weight on international travels are likely benefiting from two things: more daily steps while on vacation and, yes, food that is often healthier and less processed.‚Å†
‚Å†
Ultra-processed foods common in the U.S. include artificial additives and highly refined ingredients and are rich in starch, sugar and salt, says Dr. Dariush Mozaffarian, a cardiologist and professor of nutrition and medicine at Tufts University. He points to a study in the European Journal of Nutrition that found that among adults in the U.S., 57% of calories come from ultra-processed food, compared with 12% in Europe.‚Å†
‚Å†
What‚Äôs more, portion sizes tend to be larger in the U.S., and people drink more sodas and sugar-sweetened beverages, food researchers say. And Europeans often eat in a more leisurely way that is less prone to overeating, they note.‚Å†
‚Å†

The University of Pennsylvania is basking in the glow of two researchers who this week were awarded the Nobel Prize in medicine for their pioneering work on messenger RNA.‚Å†
‚Å†
Until recently, the school and its faculty largely disdained one of those scientists.‚Å†
‚Å†
Penn demoted Katalin Karik√≥, shunting her to a lab on the outskirts of campus while cutting her pay. Karik√≥‚Äôs colleagues denigrated her mRNA research and some wouldn‚Äôt work with her, according to her and people at the school. Eventually, Karik√≥ persuaded another Penn researcher, Drew Weissman, to work with her on modifying mRNA for vaccines and drugs, though most others at the school remained skeptical, pushing other approaches. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Karik√≥ hasn‚Äôt only proven her detractors wrong but also reached the pinnacle of science. Her research with Weissman helped lead to the mRNA vaccines that protected people worldwide during the Covid-19 pandemic and now shows promise for flu, cancer and other diseases.‚Å†
‚Å†
Penn, which patented their mRNA technology, has made millions of dollars from drugmakers that licensed it. And on Monday, when Karik√≥ and Weissman were awarded the Nobel, the school expressed a different perspective on their work.‚Å†
‚Å†
The reversal offers a glimpse of the clubby, hothouse world of academia and science, where winning financial funding is a constant burden, securing publication is a frustrating challenge and those with unconventional or ambitious approaches can struggle to gain support and acceptance.‚Å†
‚Å†

Ecuadoreans and foreigners alike have had to dramatically alter their way of life as a country that had been known for its natural beauty and relative safety quickly turned into one of the world‚Äôs most violent. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Bobbi de Winter had found her retirement paradise on Ecuador‚Äôs coast, where tiny red crabs scuttle across pristine beaches, giant sea turtles lay their eggs and whales breach the warm Pacific waters.‚Å†
‚Å†
De Winter, a native of Atlanta, and her husband, Andre, had recently finished building a house overlooking the Pacific, accessible by crossing a lush forest. They set up hammocks, planted banana and papaya trees, and hosted dinner parties as the sun set over the ocean. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Then came the drug gangs and horrific violence. Killings marred the once-sleepy district where they live, De Winter said, recalling how her husband once had to swerve his car to avoid a man who‚Äôd been shot in the street. A month after the De Winters finished their house, police found millions of dollars in cocaine stashed at a nearby beach, drugs that officers said were to be trafficked north on high-powered boats. A presidential candidate, Fernando Villavicencio, was gunned down in August. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Worried about Ecuador‚Äôs deteriorating security, the De Winters now intend to sell. ‚ÄúI had to let go of my dream,‚Äù said De Winter. ‚Å†
‚Å†
This year, Ecuador is on track to top 7,000 killings, seven times the number in 2018, government data shows.‚Å†
‚Å†
Driving the carnage is the country‚Äôs transformation into a transshipment hub for drugs from neighboring Colombia, where cocaine production hit a record high. The disarmament of Colombian drug-trafficking guerrillas in 2016 led to a power vacuum as other gangs battled to take over the routes into Ecuador, with its hundreds of miles of unguarded coast. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.‚Å†

Consumers should be spending less by now.‚Å†
‚Å†
Interest rates are up. Inflation remains high. Pandemic savings have shrunk. And the labor market is cooling.‚Å†
‚Å†
Yet household spending, the primary driver of the nation‚Äôs economic growth, remains robust. Americans spent 5.8% more in August than a year earlier, well outstripping less than 4% inflation. And the experience economy boomed this summer, with Delta Air Lines reporting record revenue in the second quarter and Ticketmaster selling over 295 million event tickets in the first six months of 2023, up nearly 18% year-over-year.‚Å†
‚Å†
Economists and financial advisers say consumers putting short-term needs and goals above long-term ones is normal. Still, this moment is different, they say.‚Å†
‚Å†
A tough housing market has more consumers writing off something they‚Äôd historically save for, while the pandemic showed the instability of any long-term plans related to health, work or day-to-day life. So, they are spending on once-in-a-lifetime experiences because they worry they may not be able to do them later.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a regret-filled, spur-of-the-moment decision,‚Äù says Michael Liersch, who oversees a team of advisers as head of advice at Wells Fargo. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the opposite of that, where I would regret not having done it.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Consumers might not be able to keep splurging forever. Labor strikes and student loan repayments could both lead people to pull back. Rising gas prices could also deter travel.‚Å†
‚Å†

At a workshop in central Ukraine, workers are busy making parts for howitzers, radar stations and mortars. They are all fakes. Ukrainian company Metinvest churns out high-quality replicas that serve as decoys, seeking to lure Russian fire.‚Å†
‚Å†
Made from rigid plastic foam, plumbing and scrap equipment, the gear is produced based on the logic that every Russian missile, shell or drone used to strike them is one fewer targeting real equipment and troops. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Replicas likely account for at least some of the weapons Russia claims to have destroyed on the battlefield, which exceed the numbers in Ukraine‚Äôs arsenal.‚Å†
‚Å†
Decoys can help mislead an enemy about attack plans or fool an opponent into believing that an area is better defended than it really is, deterring an assault. Deception has been an important tool of warfare throughout history, but the war in Ukraine has presented new challenges. Advances in thermal imaging can reveal targets that are invisible to the naked eye, or expose fakes as inert dummies. Inexpensive drones offer armies pervasive real-time surveillance, which complicates longstanding approaches to assembling or inflating replicas.‚Å†
‚Å†
Combatants say that with everything on a battlefield potentially observed, deception becomes more difficult‚Äîand more critical.‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.‚Å†
‚Å†

Hundreds of children die or are left severely injured around the country each year after they are rushed to hospital emergency rooms that are poorly prepared to treat them.‚Å†
‚Å†
Many emergency doctors don‚Äôt treat enough children to be able to spot life-threatening illnesses obscured by run-of-the-mill symptoms, or conditions more common in kids. Some E.R. staff default to drug doses and protocols meant for adults and either don‚Äôt have or don‚Äôt know where to find child-size gear in a crisis.‚Å†
‚Å†
Matthew Melancon, pictured here on the left, and Avery Guzman-Mendez, on the right, died 20 years apart after being treated at the same emergency room in Texas that was unable to successfully intubate them. The hospital, Ascension Seton Highland Lakes, hasn‚Äôt been certified under a Texas program that recognizes facilities working to upgrade their crisis care for kids.‚Å†
‚Å†
Avery‚Äôs family settled a lawsuit against the hospital earlier this year. Terms weren‚Äôt disclosed. Ascension, the health system that owns Highland Lakes, didn‚Äôt respond to requests for comment, but in court records issued a blanket denial of all the lawsuit‚Äôs allegations.‚Å†
‚Å†
Doctors, health authorities and policy makers have known‚Äîand warned‚Äîof unpreparedness for decades. Research in recent years has quantified the lack of readiness and number of child deaths that could have been avoided, and pointed to basic steps for solving the problem.‚Å†
‚Å†
Yet most hospitals haven‚Äôt taken action, according to WSJ's investigation of certification levels in all 50 states, reviews of medical records and interviews with doctors, health officials and researchers.‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio and see hospitals near you that are deemed ready for pediatric emergencies.

Bosses claim they want honest feedback when their employees are asked, "What can your manager improve on?" Telling the truth can spark change, make your work life better and show off your own assertiveness. Or you could get fired. (At least it feels that way.)‚Å†
‚Å†
Like it or not, silence isn‚Äôt an option. But you have to be really careful about just how candid to get with the boss.‚Å†
‚Å†
The average person lies three times in the first 10 minutes of meeting someone new, according to research from Robert Feldman, a professor of psychological and brain sciences at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. Such superficial fibs lubricate many of our social interactions, he says, helping us fit in and getting people to like us. ‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúAt the end of the day, we want to hear good things,‚Äù Feldman says. ‚ÄúYour boss is just like everybody else."‚Å†
‚Å†
What about when bosses want to be tapped into what‚Äôs really going on, too? After all, you‚Äôre the one who‚Äôs connected to collegial chatter and gossip, which can give managers insight into how they can do a better job and get ahead. Giving the right information to your boss can help you, too. You just have to share it the right way.‚Å†
‚Å†
A smart start is to ask some questions of your own to the boss, says Matt Abrahams, who teaches at the Stanford Graduate School of Business. What kind of guidance do they typically find useful? If they readily divulge a time they messed up or made a change, be more candid, he suggests.‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.‚Å†
‚Å†

Atlanta has been one of the Sunbelt‚Äôs biggest boomtowns, where the population and job market are growing fast. But you would never know that from its slumping office market.‚Å†
‚Å†
Vacancy rates are soaring and companies are competing to unload space in the sublease market. Office values and rents are falling. Developers are delaying new office projects, while office defaults are mounting.‚Å†
‚Å†
Atlanta‚Äôs commercial-property turmoil shows that even Sunbelt cities with thriving economies can‚Äôt escape the office-sector meltdown. Strong job growth hasn‚Äôt made up for the city‚Äôs anemic return-to-office rate, a glut of new office supply in the years leading up to the pandemic and companies shedding space as leases expire. ÔøΩÔøΩ‚Å†
‚Å†
Atlanta‚Äôs office-vacancy rate has increased to 14.7% from 11.5% at the end of 2019, according to CoStar. That is well below the 20% vacancy rate in San Francisco. But CoStar is projecting that forces such as additional company downsizing will push Atlanta office vacancies above the city‚Äôs record 16% level it hit during the 2008-09 global financial crisis.‚Å†
‚Å†
It offers an ominous warning to other cities that are hoping their office towers will fill up again when more robust economic growth returns. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.‚Å†
